abstract.text: An object that manages a tab in a tab bar.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
Navigational controls that display in a bar along the top of the screen, usually in conjunction with a navigation controller.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
The items that a navigation bar displays when the associated view controller is visible.
A container view controller that manages navigation between pages of content, where a subview controller manages each page.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A tab subclass that represents the systemâ€™s search tab.
A container view controller that implements a hierarchical interface.
The interface that determines if an object supports a spring-loaded interaction for drag and drop activities.
An object that manages a tab in a tab bar.
A tabâ€™s placement when displayed in contexts that allow different placement.
A Boolean value that indicates whether people can hide a tab in a sidebar.
A tabâ€™s badge value.
Determines if the tab has a visible placement. Returns YES if the tab is visible in a tab bar
that supports different tab placements. Otherwise returns NO.
A string identifier for a tab.
A tabâ€™s image.
Creates a tab object.
Determines if the tab is enabled. When NO, tabs will have a disabled appearance and cannot be selected by the user.
Default is YES.
A Boolean value that indicates whether an item is hidden in a sidebar.
A Boolean value that indicates whether an item is hidden by default.
The managing tab group for the tab. This returns the rootmost
in the tabâ€™s parent hierarchy with an
active
. This can be different to
if the tab is nested in multiple
levels of tab groups. If the tab does not belong to a hierarchy with a managing navigation controller, then this
will return nil. Default is nil.
The containing tab group.
The preferred placement for a tab when displayed in contexts that allow different placement.
A tabâ€™s subtitle.
The containing tab bar controller.
A tabâ€™s title.
A custom object associated with the tab.
The view controller that the system presents when someone selects a tab.
A control that displays one or more buttons in a tab bar for selecting between different subtasks, views, or modes in an app.
A container view controller that manages a multiselection interface, where the selection determines which child view controller to display.
An object that describes an item in a tab bar.
An object that manages a collection of tab objects.
Create a composite interface by combining content from one or more view controllers with other custom views.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Creating a custom container view controller

abstract.text: Provide a compact, ergonomic tab bar for quick access to key parts of your app, and a sidebar for in-depth navigation.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Elevating your iPad app with a tab bar and sidebar

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
